text.section: This section applies to a carrier with respect to any health benefit plan that is a grandfathered health plan, as defined in § 1251 of the Affordable Care Act.
A person may not offer a health benefit plan in the State unless the person offers at least the Standard Plan.
A carrier may not offer a health benefit plan that has fewer benefits than those in the Standard Plan.

A carrier may offer benefits in addition to those in the Standard Plan if:
the additional benefits:
are offered and priced separately from benefits specified in accordance with § 15-1207 of this subtitle; and
do not have the effect of duplicating any of those benefits; and
the carrier:
clearly distinguishes the Standard Plan from other offerings of the carrier;
indicates the Standard Plan is the only plan required by State law; and
specifies that all enhancements to the Standard Plan are not required by State law.

Notwithstanding subsection (c) of this section, a health maintenance organization may provide a point of service delivery system as an additional benefit through another carrier regardless of whether the other carrier also offers the Standard Plan.
A carrier may offer coverage for dental care and services as an additional benefit.

section.section: In this subsection, "prominent carrier" means a carrier that insures at least 10% of the total lives insured in the small group market.
A prominent carrier shall offer a wellness benefit for a health benefit plan offered under this subtitle.
A carrier that is not a prominent carrier may offer a wellness benefit for a health benefit plan offered under this subtitle.
A carrier may not condition the sale of a wellness benefit to a small employer on participation of the eligible employees of the small employer in wellness programs or activities.
